headline: Easy Italian Peperonata
description: This saucy mix of ultra tender bell peppers, garlic, and herbs is an Italian classic.
recipeIngredient: 4  large bell peppers (about 2 1/2 pounds total), preferably a mix of red, orange, and yellow
1 teaspoon kosher salt, plus more as needed

recipeInstructions.name: Step 1
recipeInstructions.text: Prepare the following, adding each to the same large bowl as it is completed: Stem, seed, and thinly slice 4 large bell peppers. Thinly slice 1 small yellow onion. Thinly slice 3 garlic cloves.

recipeInstructions.name: Step 2
recipeInstructions.text: Heat 3 tablespoons olive oil in a 12-inch high-sided skillet or a large Dutch oven over medium heat until shimmering. Add the bell peppers mixture, season with 1 teaspoon kosher salt and 1/4 teaspoon black pepper, and cook, stirring occasionally, until the peppers are softened but still crisp-tender, 10 to 12 minutes.

recipeInstructions.name: Step 3
recipeInstructions.text: Add 2 tablespoons tomato paste and saut√® until the vegetables are coated and the paste darkens in color, 1 to 2 minutes. Pour in 1/2 cup water. Add 1 of the fresh oregano sprigs and 1/4 teaspoon red pepper flakes, if desired. Stir to combine. Cover, reduce the heat to low, and simmer until the peppers are very soft and tender, 25 to 27 minutes.

recipeInstructions.name: Step 4
recipeInstructions.text: Meanwhile, strip the leaves from the remaining 2 fresh oregano sprigs and coarsely chop.

recipeInstructions.name: Step 5
recipeInstructions.text: When the peppers are ready, remove the pan from the heat. Discard the oregano sprig. Add 1 tablespoon balsamic vinegar and stir to combine. Taste and season with more kosher salt as needed. Garnish with chopped oregano. Serve warm, at room temperature, or cold.

HowtoTip.text: Storage: Leftovers can be refrigerated in an airtight container for up to 5 days.

name: Easy Italian Peperonata

author.name: Sheela Prakash
author.description: Sheela is the Senior Contributing Food Editor at Kitchn and the author of Mediterranean Every Day: Simple, Inspired Recipes for Feel-Good Food. She received her master's degree from the University of Gastronomic Sciences in Italy and is also a Registered Dietitian.
